My youngest daughter recently enjoyed two weeks of holiday, called the May Holiday. The first day of her holiday was Good Friday, April 19. It is Dutch logic to call that a May Holiday. Dutch Public holidays are not fixed days, so they change every year. This year it is an employer-friendly year as, for example, King‚Äôs Day and Liberation day both fell in the weekend. Unfortunately, other than for instance in the UK, such days are not moved to the next Monday in the Netherlands.

King‚Äôs Day is now April 27 as that is the birthday of our King. Before King Willem-Alexander ascended the throne, we enjoyed Queens Day which fell on April 30 and was always the start of that holiday in May. On Queen‚Äôs Day, April 30, 2013, Queen Beatrix abdicated in favor of her eldest son and resumed the title of princess. But April 30 was not the birthday of Beatrix as that is January 31. It was the birthday of her mother and Willem Alexanders‚Äô Grandma Juliana instead. Since the Dutch are used to celebrate the day outside all dressed up in orange, she thought January would be too cold for the people and decided not to move the day of celebration to her own birthday.

In my memory, Queen‚Äôs Day has always been a warm and shiny day indeed. But since it moved to King‚Äôs Day on April 27, it has always been a colder day than January that same year. Dutch logic again. Our future Queen, if all stays well, will be Amalia who is born on December 7. We will have to see what happens with her birthday celebrations. By the way, this is one of the reasons the Netherlands is a Triple-A country. Amalia is the first A, her sisters are called Alexia and Ariane.

My oldest daughter is taking exams this year; hence she is studying each day to pass her exams to start the next phase in her and our life as parents: going to a university and leaving the house. She is looking forward to it, we as parents only partly. We found it inappropriate to go on holiday somewhere without her while she was studying and us making fun. So, we decided to stay at home these weeks and take a day off here and there and do something fun with our youngest daughter. My son is too old for that, he claims.

Accordingly, we visited the MuZIEum last week, which maybe best translates to MuSEEum. Where in most museums you can see beautiful things, this one lets you experience what is it like to be blind or partially sighted. You are entering a world in which your other senses ‚Äì hearing, smell, touch and taste ‚Äì suddenly play a far more important role than you are used to.

So, it is not a museum where you admire objects on displays or walls. We were an essential part of the experience by doing a tour through a living room, a garden, a supermarket, and drinking a soda in a bar in absolute darkness. You literally see not a thing. Our tour guide called Joop is 100% blind and told more about living with sight loss. He made us see the world through different eyes. They say that in the country of the blind the one-eyed man is king. I can tell you that in the MuZIEum, Joop was king and not me or Willem-Alexander.

Walking around in the world of Microsoft, it sometimes feels like walking around in the MuZIEum. In the Microsoft country, the one-eyed man is king. Being a Microsoft partner, there are so many opportunities, but it is hard to choose which ones to follow. You cannot pursue them all. On April 17, Microsoft announced a new program for Business Application Independent Software Vendors (ISV‚Äôs), following many initiatives like Certified for Microsoft Dynamics, AppSource, One Commercial Partner and more. This time the program is designed by Microsoft veteran Steven ‚ÄòGuggs‚Äô Guggenheimer. In his blog, Steve writes that by 2022, the business applications market will reach USD 125 billion ‚Äì a 43% increase from 2018! ‚Äì with ISV‚Äôs projected to drive 57% of the business applications business (based on internal research commissioned by Microsoft).

With this new ISV program, Microsoft says they are ensuring customers are offered only the highest-quality and most secure apps. This is the same text as used with the Certified for Microsoft Dynamics program. A big difference with CfMD is that business applications are now cloud-based: offering Microsoft more tools, insights and enforcement to make this happen. The program is built around a revenue-sharing model that offers reinvestment in ISVs through new technology, marketing, and sales enablement benefits. Looking at the projected revenue growth, I know which eyed man is becoming king. Following the reduction of margins of their reselling partners, Microsoft is now eating a part of the ISV side of the Business Application pie. Despite this behavior, which might seem a bit greedy, partners who survived the reduced reselling margins have only grown, both in revenue and profits. Fortunately, HSO is one of them.

Continuity is most important for customers who invest in business applications, and Microsoft and HSO Innovation are in for the long term.

Staying at home also means having time to clean the house and finally get rid of stuff you never use. One of the traditions at Kings day in the Netherlands is it is free to sell anything you like during that day. It is called vrijmarkt or kleedjesmarkt, which translates as a free marketplace or carpet market as most sellers sit on a kind of carpet. My youngest daughter thought she could make some money offering her second-hand clothes for resale on King‚Äôs Day.

With the money earned she would be able to pay us back for the new nice dress she bought for herself for the coming summer but did not yet have the money to buy (I will get back to this at the end of this blog). Optimistically, she went to the free market and assumed the new owners would be very happy with her clothes. Some potential buyers looked and showed interest in her beautiful green dress and let all the other stuff untouched. Someone offered $30 for the green dress, but she had given the dress a price tag of $59.99. My daughter‚Äôs response was that it is worth much more, as she had barely worn it. The buyer responded with: ‚ÄúLook around. Would you spend so much on a similar second-hand dress?‚Äù. Disappointed my daughter put everything, including her green dress, in her bag and came home. When thinking it over before going to sleep, she said the potential buyer was probably right. Why expect to get $60 for something you would not pay more for than $40? People tend to overestimate the value of their belongings as it hurts to say goodbye to them. This is called the endowment effect: the finding that people are more likely to retain an object they own than acquire that same object when they do not own it. The pain of losing things with a perceived loss is larger than the happiness of acquiring them. Or even worse, the possession of things for some is the end of the entertainment. The repugnance of loss makes people not wanting to sell at all. It not only applies to small things like a dress but also with more substantial investments like a house, stocks, and probably business applications.

One of my favorite Professors, Daniel Kahneman and his colleagues Jack Knetsch & Richard Thaler conducted a study to see how the endowment effect influences our decision making. The scientists randomly divided participants into buyers and sellers and gave the sellers HSO coffee mugs as a gift. They then asked the sellers for how much they would sell the mug and asked the buyers for how much they would buy it.

Results showed that the sellers (who owned the mugs) placed a significantly higher value on the mugs than the buyers did. They were willing to sell a mug for $7.12 while buyers were only willing to pay $2.87 (median reservation prices).

People appreciate things that they already own more than things they might own. The fear of losing the mug (loss aversion) becomes the cause of the contradiction in the evaluation of the cost of the coffee mug.

The fear of losing the mug (loss aversion) becomes the cause of the contradiction in the evaluation of the cost of the coffee mug.

With Microsoft taking a part of our revenue, this either means lower revenue for us and/or for the reselling partner. Alternatively, we can increase subscription fees, but that would probably increase the endowment effect. When in sales it is important to understand this effect. Changing the price should be avoided but is always a possibility. It is easier to bridge a price gap than a functional gap in software.

The idea of ownership and endowment effect is starting early in our life and is further explained in these videos:

HSO Innovation offers business apps on Microsoft AppSource. Our most successful apps are the apps where users can perform a free trial. Microsoft will introduce the transact option to AppSource later this year. The neoclassical preference theory predicts that notions of value are independent of initial endowments or commitments. In fact, the ubiquity of the endowment effect is so high, it‚Äôs been used to explain why bidders end up paying more in frenzied eBay auctions or why investors hold onto loss-making stocks But how does the effect help us when it comes to designing apps, attracting users and keeping them? Only Apps that are sufficiently addictive and encourage regular engagement thrive. Given 35% of mobile app engagements last less than a minute, being able to harness behavioral phenomena ‚Äì like the endowment effect ‚Äì can be key to boosting user loyalty in a severely attention-deficient world. Applying what we know about the endowment effect, apps can incorporate certain design elements to gain long-term traction. The reason why ‚Äòfreemium‚Äô, like Spotify and Pok√©mon Go, is popular is that it minimizes people‚Äôs perceived cost of being locked into something they may not want to pay for, but is giving them the feeling of ownership, making it less likely the user will abandon the product when the free period ends. Thanks to the endowment effect, people think twice before hitting the uninstall button. And as people place more value on something they own than if they don‚Äôt own it, they might be willing to pay more for a product after experiencing a free trial than they would if they had to pay for the product without it. With consumer apps, the most successful apps make use of conditional rewards and FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out) effect (level-ups, points, badges and prizes) with the risk of being lost if you don‚Äôt return frequently. The endowment effect tells us this capitalizes on people‚Äôs tendency towards loss aversion, the tendency for us to feel the pain of loss more strongly than pleasure at an equal gain. But all the neurological insights in the world couldn‚Äôt save an app that is perceived to lack fundamental user value. However, design that taps into the powerful nuances of the endowment effect can augment a good one in terms of greater product adoption, user retention and app loyalty.

I promised to end with the money my daughter borrowed from us to buy that nice dress. She lends $50 from her mother and $50 from me. The dress was $97, so she had $3 left. She returns $1 to each of us and decided to keep that $1. This means she will have to return $49 to both of us later. But wait a minute: $49 + $49 = $98 + that $1 she kept, makes it $99. Where did that $1 go???

$1 per month per user is making Microsoft the big King.

Kind regards,

Eric Veldkamp

Last week my daughter and I attended a theater lecture by the famous Dutch physician and neurobiologist Dick Swaab. Dick Swaab is best known for his research and discoveries in the field of brain anatomy and physiology and the impact that various hormonal and biochemical factors in the womb have on brain development. His book ‚ÄòWe are our brains ‚Äì a travel through brains‚Äô, describes Dick‚Äôs conclusion that brains are not things we have, but rather brains are what we are: the physical and chemical processes in our brains determine how we react and who we are.

The lecture was organized around his new book ‚ÄòOur creative brain‚Äô. For me, the lecture was especially interesting because of the topic and content, not so much based on Dick‚Äôs presentation skills. It departed from the big five personality traits, also known as the five-factor model (FFM) and the OCEAN or CANOE Model. The five factors have been defined as openness to experience, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism.

Beneath each proposed global factor, there are several correlated and more specific primary factors. For example, extraversion is said to include such related qualities as gregariousness, assertiveness, excitement seeking, warmth, activity, and positive emotions.

During the lecture, Dick presented several exceptional examples of human brains and people who see the world differently than average humans do. Not only with visual illusions people register and see different things while looking at the same thing. What you see is not always what you get. What you see is not always what is actually there and what you see is not always what someone else sees. Please have a look at a Kanizsa triangle illusion below that make us realize the way our visual systems work.

How many triangles do you see? It is an illusory contour, a symmetrical figure consisting of 3 discs each missing a triangular section, and 3 pairs of lines. Looking at the figure, most people will have the visual experience of an apparent brightness contour defining an upright triangle which is occluding three black discs and a second, inverted triangle outlined in black. In fact, these triangles do not exist! If you then consider that memories fade, and people have difficulties in gathering and presenting info from their long-term memory, you can imagine for instance in court cases it is hard to use eye witness stories.

Anyway, I‚Äôd like to share some more examples presented by Dick with you as well. Two years ago, in my blog on Argument from Ignorance I wrote about PI Day, March 14 (Yes, it is coming soon again!). Dick talked about the man who memorized PI (a circles circumference divided by its diameter), Daniel Tammet, memorizing 22,514 digits in just over 5 hours! This is an example of synesthesia, a puzzling phenomenon in which a certain type of stimulus triggers a hallucinatory perception. Daniel is an autistic savant and wrote and TED talks about his life with Asperger syndrome and Savant Syndrome.

Savants became known with the filming of Rain Man, a 1988 movie telling the story of an abrasive, selfish young wheeler-dealer Charlie Babbitt (Tom Cruise), who discovers that his estranged father has died and bequeathed all of his multimillion-dollar estate to his other son, Raymond (Dustin Hoffman), of whose existence Charlie was unaware. Raymond is an autistic savant. Savants like Rain Man have very low mental performance in most areas. However, they also have unusually high performance at a very small number of things.

Back to Daniel. Daniel is also able to do seemingly impossible calculations in his head with incredible speed, as well as learn to speak and write new languages, like Icelandic in about a week. Tammet doesn‚Äôt need a calculator to solve exponential math problems such as 27 to the 7th power ‚Äì that‚Äôs 27 multiplied by itself seven times ‚Äì he‚Äôll come up with the answer 10,460,353,203 in a few seconds. Like a powerful computer! One word that he uses quite frequently is ‚Äúlandscape‚Äù. When Tammet recites a number with numerable digits (Pi, for example), he sees a landscape that consists of the shapes that are representative of each integer. By making his way through the landscape in his mind, he can see (and recite) each digit in eerily perfect sequential order. If you are interested to learn more about Daniel, I encourage you to watch the documentary: Daniel Tammet ‚Äì The Boy With The Incredible Brain‚Äù.

Another exceptional savant example is Stephen Wiltshire, also known as The Human Camera. Stephen drew the cities of London, Rome and more just from memory by flying around in a helicopter. Stephens verbal IQ has been measured at 52 but learning about Stephen is enough to make you wonder if ‚Äònormal‚Äô intelligence is all it‚Äôs cracked up to be. According to the voiceover, after just 45 minutes of surveying Rome from a helicopter, Wiltshire was able to faithfully recreate virtually everything he saw. His completed panorama stretched across 5 and a half yards of paper. Even more impressive, Steven‚Äôs masterpiece required no preliminary sketching, or ‚Äòroughing out of space.‚Äô ‚ÄúIt was as if the panorama already existed in his head, with all the proportions, all the roads, all the details.‚Äù You should have a look at this video on drawing Rome, as mentioned a city he never visited before:

Stephen has shown us that while most of us seem intent to be bound by the shackles of what we determine to be ‚Äòreal‚Äô or ‚Äòpossible‚Äô, others like Stephen are out there actually pushing the limits and showing us all how narrow-minded and naive we all are. In Stephens own words on what we can learn from him: ‚ÄúI would say that I have overcome many hurdles in life, even when it seemed that I would never get there or people would assume so, I have grown confident and challenge myself every day. I keep working on my skills to become even better than I am now. I believe in myself and my work, and I do the best I can and never stop.‚Äù If you want to learn more on Steven, check this documentary:

So, we talked about computer and intelligence and from Steven, the Human Camera, it is easy to switch to the recent release of Microsoft HoloLens 2 which also contains a camera to realize virtual and augmented reality. At the end of February, Microsoft used the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona to announce the next version of its HoloLens mixed reality visor. Check these reviews on the websites of techcrunch.com and cnet.com.

Dick Swaab and many others say that in order to keep your brains in shape (and postpone dementia) you should continuously challenge and stimulate them. This can be done by expressing creativity, for instance in art or with music. It can promote social coherence, improve the mood and reduce pain when used in therapy. Using the HoloLens can open a new world of brain stimulation.

According to Dick Swaab, it is not a big jump from one autistic disorder to other disorders, like psychopathy. If you think psychopaths are far away from you, you should look around you. When talking about psychopaths, people automatically think of serial killers or other strange characters, like Ted Bundy, Charles Manson or Jack the Ripper. I don‚Äôt want to make you scared, but do you know which professions have the most psychopaths and which have the fewest? You will be surprised to find out that CEO is the profession with the most psychopaths. Here is the overview:

To calm you down, psychopath doesn‚Äôt just mean someone who cuts you up with a chainsaw üòä. I am more on the left side than the right side. If you want to learn more about this, check this website. On which side are you?

Back to brain stimulation and the HoloLens. Does it stimulate the brain when combined with Artificial Intelligence? I wrote about Artificial intelligence as being the end of Homo Sapiens in my November 2017 blog. Yuval Noah Harari is convinced that within 20 years Google algorithms will know us better than we know ourselves and I mentioned I am not convinced Yuval is right. We talked about AI during the Dick Swaab lecture and he confirmed that AI can indeed do some things better than humans (like playing chess or make a specific forecast) but doing different things at the same time by connecting various zones like the human brain can, will take long before that gets in motion with AI. Despite the worrying rhetoric about AI coming to take your jobs, lives, freedom and general sense of purpose, it‚Äôs been most successful when applied to narrow problems and, even then, constrained by the smartness of humans around it. In that blog, I already mentioned intelligent algorithms are idiot savants.

It is easy to forgive people for thinking that deep learning is incredibly intelligent. However, once you dig into deep learning, you‚Äôll find that as opposed to being a generally brilliant algorithm it compares more with a Savant than with Albert Einstein, considering Albert Einstein was a very intelligent human being. AI is a Savant. In other words, a deep learning process is really smart at a specific task or two, but not smart at all for anything else.

To prove that some algorithms are not even doing that one task very well, I give you the example of Facebook banning a user from posting a photo of a 30,000-year-old statue of a naked woman. The Venus of Willendorf, which dates back 29,500 years, is considered one of the world‚Äôs earliest depictions of female fertility and Facebook algorithm censored it as being pornographic. The Natural History Museum of Vienna, which houses the figurine, has attacked Facebook and they apologized for censoring that prehistoric figurine and said it being an incident.

So, what AI enabled machines still are is an idiot savant. When we saw Rain Man we saw Raymond still needs his brother to focus that attention to a specific problem, define it for him, help prune the hypotheses and help him learn. After that, he became a useful idiot savant, but still nowhere close to an entity that will take your job in any given moment. An interesting book on AI is a book by Prof. Marvin Minsky. In his book, Society of Mind, Dr. Minsky approaches AI from a high and practical level, describing the mind as an aggregation of specialized units that evolve to perform specific tasks. (This part is inspired by an article written by Paolo Pignatelli). It is based on the assumptions that the statistical manipulations that we use today under the name of Artificial Intelligence are, ‚Äòintelligent‚Äô. They are intelligent in that they do what we tell them to do.

A pigeon will return to its home, but is a pigeon intelligent? It is certainly more intelligent than most AI devices of the same size. Intelligent? There is some scare talk now about how dangerous AI face recognition is, but cats and dogs do it all the time. We properly distinguish between a genius‚Äô intelligence and that of a savant even when they perform similar tasks. Intelligence may well be some optimal collaboration of smaller units. Without a critical level of collaboration, we do not call a person‚Äôs mind ‚Äòintelligent‚Äô. Take a vow of Microsoft Azure AI, a pinch of AWS terabyte storage, a dash of NVIDIA, a spoonful of Alphabet TensorFlow, and voil√†, the evil genius that we need legislate against. Naturally, this is poppycock! A society of artificial idiot savants, which is where we are right now in the development of machine intelligence, poses no more danger to society than a society of human ones. We are grateful for the idiot savants amongst us now, for their gifts illuminate our understanding of intelligence and of society.

Even with all the amazing examples of progress in artificial intelligence, such as self-driving cars and the victories of AlphaGo, the technology is still very narrow in its accomplishments and far from autonomous. Ergo, today‚Äôs machine-learning systems are AI savants. Self-driving cars and speech recognition are based on machine learning. If you want to learn how machines learn you should watch this video:

And even today, 99 percent of machine learning is based on human work. Machine learning still needs large amounts of data, all of which needs to be labeled (Metadata): this is a dog; this is a cat, that is a pigeon and then people need to supply the appropriate algorithms. All this relies on manual labor. The key to recognizing the limitations of today‚Äôs AI is understanding the difference between autonomy and intelligence. People have both. AI systems, even if they have very high intelligence for a specific task, tend to be low in autonomy. And that lack of autonomy limits the technology‚Äôs ability to take on many broad problems. Despite the limitations, there are many potential applications in science, healthcare and other sectors. AI is a tool, the choice of how it gets deployed is a human choice. Model building, instead of pattern recognition, can help AI systems develop new skills, like playing an unfamiliar game or recognizing new handwritten characters. The study of the human mind will play a key role in developing this technology in the future.

In our spotlight article ‚ÄòTrends impacting the Rental Industry‚Äô, we give some examples of how AI can add value to the rental industry in help making decisions. Rental items, similar to pigeons, typically return home. Very ‚Äòintelligent‚Äô items and even worse than pigeons as the items rented sometimes return home in a different shape or size (think of scaffolding), actually being another item. See also our spotlight item ‚ÄòDifferences between Bulk, Serialized and Project Driven rental types‚Äô.

Average ERP systems cannot handle that very well. They try to use the RMA process for returned rental items. Our Dynamics Rental Management solution for Microsoft Dynamics 365 for Finance and Operations supports this process very well. A very intelligent solution, but only when used by intelligent users that feed the system with proper data.

Kind regards,

Eric Veldkamp

For many, the end of the year is full of traditions. Some say it is the most wonderful time of the year. The whole world takes on a magic glow, people seem merrier and in the Northern hemisphere, the winter including artificial lights somehow feels as if it is cozier. Whether you are celebrating a religious festival, like Hanukkah or Christmas, or a more secular occasion, you are sure to have your own selection of traditions, rituals or customs that make the holiday season and life in general so special. Christmas is only one of the traditions and there are several remarkable events happening around the world.

For instance, Ligligan Parul Sampernandu (Giant Lantern Festival) is held each year on the Saturday before Christmas Eve in the city of San Fernando. The festival attracts spectators from all over the country and across the globe. Eleven barangays or villages take part in the festival and competition is fierce as everyone pitches in trying to build the most elaborate lantern. Originally, the lanterns were simple creations around half a meter in diameter, made from papel de hapon (Japanese origami paper) and lit by a candle. Today, the lanterns are made from a variety of materials and have grown to around six meters in size. They are illuminated by electric bulbs that sparkle in a kaleidoscope of patterns.

Or what to think of G√§vle Goat in Sweden. Since 1966, a 13-meter-tall Yule Goat has been built in the center of G√§vle‚Äôs Castle Square for the Advent, but this Swedish Christmas tradition has unwittingly led to another tradition of sorts: people trying to burn it down. Since 1966 the Goat has been successfully burned down 29 times and the most recent destruction was in 2016.

Austria shows the evil Santa Claus with Krampus. Japan is not doing so much with Christmas but has a Kentucky Fried Christmas Dinner. The Icelandic have the Yule Lads. Perhaps one of the most unorthodox Christmas Eve traditions can be found in Norway, where people hide their brooms. It is a tradition that dates back centuries when people believed that witches and evil spirits came out on Christmas Eve looking for brooms to ride on. To this day, many people still hide their brooms in the safest place in the house to stop them from being stolen.

The US has, amongst other things, the Lighting of National Hanukkah Menorah, Washington D.C. If you want to have a rolling Christmas, you better go to Caracas, Venezuela. Every Christmas Eve, the city‚Äôs residents head to church in the early morning ‚Äì nothing special ‚Äì but, for some reason, they do so on roller skates. This unique tradition is so popular that roads across the city are closed to cars so that people can skate to church in safety, before heading home for the less-than-traditional Christmas dinner of tamales, a wrap made from cornmeal dough and stuffed with meat and then steamed. Colombia has the Day of the Little Candles, where Toronto Canada is celebrating Cavalcade of Lights.

Besides the end of the year traditions, each country has its own, sometimes very strange customs. They may appear a little odd to some, but to others, they are part of their history and heritage. The US recently celebrated Thanksgiving Day followed by Black Friday, Ciber Monday and #Giving Tuesday.

Have you ever heard of the popular Swedish drinking game pen-in-bottle? Do you know what Jarping is? Or the reason why a bunch of people choose to hurl themselves down a steep hill in pursuit of a large wheel of cheese each year? There are various flavors of celebrating carnival, but the one in Ivrea Italy is based on a locally famous Battle of the Oranges.

And what to think of 5 parties for 1 celebration? Wedding celebrations can involve five parties in some parts of the Middle East, beginning with the engagement party and ending with the wedding shower, seven days after the marriage.

You better take along your umbrella if you‚Äôre in Poland on ≈ömigus Dyngus, also known as Wet Monday. ≈ömigus Dyngus is an opportunity to stage the ultimate water fight. Held each year on Easter Monday in Poland and Ukraine, participants blast each other with water to celebrate Easter.

Finger-pulling is no laughing matter in the Alps. Finger wrestling was once used to settle disputes but is now a competition that is taken quite seriously by the contenders. The winner is the person who manages to pull the other contestant across the table, using only his or her finger! Contenders pick their digit carefully and subject it to rigorous training regimes involving crushing tennis balls and doing one finger pull-ups!

In the UK every Spring Bank Holiday near Gloucester sees the annual Cooper‚Äôs Hill Cheese-Rolling and Wake take place. Participants line up in groups of about twenty to chase after a substantial wheel of cheese as it descends perilously down a steep incline. This ‚Äúworld-famous event‚Äù often results in injuries to onlookers, a great lump of cheese is quite a hazard when rolled down a hill at speed. Also, in the UK, jarping is a game where you try crack someone else‚Äôs boiled egg without cracking your own. This is very popular in North-East England and there‚Äôs even a World Jarping Championships in Peterlee, Durham, each Easter.

The ridiculous but fun pen-in-bottle drinking game in Sweden involves securing a pen on a length of string tied around one‚Äôs waist and then competing to be the first person to lower one‚Äôs pen into an empty bottle using one‚Äôs waist. Last but not least I‚Äôd like to mention Tomato craze in Spain: La Tomatina. It is a strange culture among the Valencians in Bunol where the biggest tomato fight that exists is held.

If you are interested to learn more on traditions by country you should check this page at Wikipedia. I don‚Äôt think the overview is complete, so you are invited to enrich the list with your own country‚Äôs traditions.

Exactly 4 years ago I wrote about Black Friday as well as a particular tradition we have in the Netherlands called Sinterklaas. This tradition is under significant pressure since it became controversial and you see a change in the way it celebrated. Is that a problem? Not really, at least that is what I think (and so does Olaf Tempelman, a Volkskrant journalist in an article on December 1, 2018). Spanish bullfighting, Australian dwarf tossing, Sinterklaas, each controversial tradition is subject to change or will eventually stop. As Woody Allen said in Deconstructing Harry: ‚ÄúTradition is the illusion of permanence.‚Äù Some people may think that traditions exist for centuries in the same form. But if we look at Sinterklaas only a couple of decennia ago, Black Pete changed from somebody who scared the children to a children‚Äôs friend and catalyst of retail purchases. Even without being disputed for racism the metamorphose would have happened, but at a slower pace. And the fact that it now happens under full attention has the same effect as waking the sleeping dogs. A judge already concluded that Black Pete is unnecessary hurting black compatriots, but you cannot put a tradition in jail.

Traditions are hard to ban and result in recalcitrance. The British fox hunt was abandoned in 2004 in the Hunting Act. Even this year almost every Sunday costumed horsemen chase foxes and so are the little people still flying through the air in Australian pubs and even babies in Maharashtra India. Since traditions touch people‚Äôs emotions, it is hard to change them fast or forced, like that oil tanker turning. Traditions link to memories and the identity of a country or region. Cutting a tradition is different than stopping death penalties or compulsory military service.

Each tradition is unique, but the behavior of supporters is most often the same. Each tradition under fire results in dividing the community where the tradition exists. In that sense, Sinterklaas can be compared with the bullfighting in Castile and Catalonia Spain, where the entry of Sinterklaas is like the San Fermin festivities in Pamplona. People who are against bullfighting fight with fans which leads to injuries without any bull involved! The activism is having an effect though, since bullfighting became controversial. And so is Black Pete at Sinterklaas. Black Pete is slowly changing into various colored versions, like Rainbow Pete, Stroopwafel Pete or Soot Sweeper Pete as a non-controversial Pete, and that is fine. Francis Fukuyama described tradition as the cement of society. A non-controversial tradition is evolving with the community. A controversial tradition only survives in cleared or unruly versions. Instead of dwarf‚Äôs, ordinary people wearing helmets fly through the Australian pubs. Here is the story of Pete and Mary playing a game which I read in a column of Ionica Smeets. There are 4 vases filled with 5 marbles. Each vase has 4 white and 1 red marble. They both may pick 4 marbles from 1 or more vases blindfolded. The person with the largest number of red marbles wins the game. Pete may start and decides to pick a marble from each vase. Mary decides to pick the remaining 4 marbles from 1 vase. Who do you think has the biggest chance of winning? Pete seems very smart as Mary can only pick 1 red marble at max and he has a chance of picking 4 red marbles!

Let‚Äôs calculate their chances and start with Mary‚Äôs point of view. Her chance of picking a red marble is zero (0) or one (1). The chance of her picking zero red marbles is one-fifth (1/5), because that is the chance of Pete picking that 1 red marble from her vase. If that is the case, then Pete always has a higher chance of picking the most red marbles. This way his chance of winning is 1/5.

But now let‚Äôs look at it from a different perspective. Mary has a chance of 4/5 to pick a red marble. Then there are 3 more potential results:

If Pete did not pick a red marble at all, Mary wins

If Pete exactly picked 1 red marble, they end equally

and if Pete has more than 1 red marble he wins

In case 1) the chance of Pete not picking a red marble out of the first vase is 4/5. The vases are independent and the chance of Mary winning is 4/5 x 4/5 x 4/5 x 4/5 = 256/625 or around 41 %.

In case 2) Mary has 1 red marble and the chance of Pete picking one red marble from the other 3 vases is 3 x 1/5 x 4/5 x 4/5 = 48/125 (need to multiply by 3 since the red marble may come from any of the 3 vases). And then further multiplied by the chance of Mary picking 1 red marble makes it a chance of 192/625 or ¬± 31% to equal.

In case 3) the chance of Pete beating Mary with a larger number of red marbles is 52/625 (feel free to make the calculation üòä and if you enjoy doing this, then do this again with vases filled with n white marbles and 1 red marble). Adding the 1/5 chance of Mary picking zero red marbles makes Pete‚Äôs chance of winning 177/625 or ¬± 28%.

Double check: 41% + 31% + 28% = 100 % (Yes!). So: Mary by far has the best chance to win with the strategy she followed. Having 1 red marble is often enough to win. The lesson for politicians and companies: it is better to win by forming a coalition and win with a narrow majority than with trying to gather a huge majority for only a few of your proposals, topics or products.

William Feller discovered that people easily see a pattern in random situations.
